> 
> Well.. in my implementation, when you split two nodes (a,b), you  
> a=
lways get a specific location.  So, what you describe isn't the case.
> 
> =
Think of it as each node having a pair of coordinates on a 2D  
> Cartesian=
 grid.  If your network starts out with, for example, one  
> input node, o=
ne bias node, and one output node, you might assign them  
> initial positi=
ons of:
> 
> Node0: Input: 0,0
> Node1: Bias: 0,1
> Node2: Output: 1,0.5
> =

> I'm not going to attempt ASCII art b/c Yahoo groups botches  
> everythi=
ng.  But basically, this network is flowing from left to right.
> 
> Now, s=
ay you split 1 and 2.  You get a node between them; it's at  
> (0.5,0.75) =
using our imaginary 2D system.
> 
> So, Node3 is always refers to a single =
specific node.  Hence NodeX  
> does as well...  and so, Link (x,y) should =
also always be the same,  
> and so yes, it should share the innovation num=
ber.
> 
> I'm sorry that I did not explain this very eloquently; but, I hop=
e I  
> got everything correct.
> 
> --Steve
>
Steve,

Thanks again for the=

1             0   2        =

3             1=
   3        0,1       0.5,0.75

=

Now, for a 2nd genome, instead of splitting from node 1 to 2, we split
nod=
e 0 to 2
and get node 3 in a different position, the innovations table beco=
mes

0       1,0.5

 3        0,1       0.5,0.75

           0   3        0,0       0.5,0.25

.25  1,0.5

 links,
